section.title: Leveling
section.para: Data obtained from SPM microscope are very often not leveled at all - microscope outputs directly raw data values computed from piezoscanner voltage, strain gauge, interferometer or other detection system values. This way of exporting data enables user to choose his/her own way of leveling data.

Choosing the leveling mode should be done depending on your SPM system configuration. Basically, for systems with independent scanner(s) for each axis plane leveling should be sufficient and for systems with scanner(s) moving in all three axes (tube scanners) 2nd order polynomial leveling should be used.

Of course, you can use higher order leveling for any data, however, this can supress real features on the surface (namely waviness of the surface) and therefore alter the statistical functions and quantities evaluated from the surface.

The simplest modules that ace connected with data leveling are Fix Zero and Zero Mean Value that simply set the average height of the data to put minimum to zero (Fix Zero) or mean value to zero (Zero Mean Value). These modules can be accessed through the following menu choices:

section.title: Plane Level
section.para: Plane leveling is usually one of the firsts function applied to raw SPM data. The plane is computed from all the image points and is subtracted from the data.

section.title: Three point leveling
section.para: Three point leveling tool can be used for leveling very complicated surface structures. User can simply mark three points in the image that should be at the same level. Plane is computed from these three points and is subtracted from data.

section.title: Facet Level
section.para: Levels data by subtracting a plane like the standard Level function does. However, the plane is determined differently: it makes facets of the surface as horizontal as possible. Thus for surfaces with flat horizontal areas it leads to much better results than the standard Level. On the other hand, for random surfaces it can behave much worse compared to Level.

section.title: Level Rotate
section.para: Does similar things as plane leveling, however does not simply subtract the fitted plane from the data. Instead of it, this module takes the plane parameters and rotates image data by given amount to make it lying in plane. In comparison to plane level, this modules should therefore preserve angles in the data.

section.title: Background subtraction
section.para: Basically, background can be extracted using many modules generating some filtered data, using the Data Arithmetics module. However, there are special modules for backgrund subtraction too implemented in Gwyddion. All allow to extract subtracted background to a separate data window.

section.title: Polynomial Background
section.para: Fits data by polynom of given order (generally the order can be different for X and Y axis) and subtracts this polynom.

section.title: Revolve Arc
section.para: Revolves virtual `arc' of given radius horizontally of vertically over (or under) data. Envelope of this arcs is treated as a background, resulting in removal of features larger than arc radius (approximately).

section.title: Median Level
section.para: Filters data with a median filter with large kernel and treats the result as background, keeping only features smaller than approximately kernel size. This method is very slow.
